WASHINGTON UNHERALDED and almost unnoticed, the most important signs of a new regulatory approach appeared recently when the Environmental Protection Agency formally proposed adopting the "bubble concept" for controlling air pollution. Industry would be left free to do whatever it wanted within the bubble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4--The Forest Service today signaled the beginning of another conservation battle by recommending that 36 million additional acres of roadless land within the National Forests be opened for timber cutting, mining and motorized recreation and by calling for the creation of 15 million acres of new wilderness areas.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 (AP) The largest study ever conducted on women who take estrogen in menopause concludes that the medicine can cause cancer of the uterus and that the risk increases the longer the medicine is used.

Mayor Koch yesterday announced a series of cuts he is likely to order to close next year's budget gap, and said he was relying on the state and Federal governments to give the city more than two-thirds of the $439 million it needs to eliminate the deficit.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 An aggressive and slightly desperate band of Philadelphia Flyers handed the New York Islanders one of their rare National Hockey League defeats tonight, rebounding from a 2-0 deficit early in the second period to register a 3-2 triumph before a capacity crowd of 17,077 at the Spectrum. They did it with three power-play goals in the second period, the final one by Bobby Clarke.
TOKYO,Jan. 4 (AP) Japan's gold and foreign exchange reserves stand at a record high $33 billion after gaining $10.1 billion in 1978, the Finance Ministry reported today.

In its zeal to encourage the release of petty delinquents, has the Federal Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention neglected the possibility of helping serious offenders? Are they being held in state correctional facilities with too little thought about alternatives providing greater individual attention to their prospects after release?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Although the United States supports Cambodia's request for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia, it is not committed to a particular position in that debate, the State Department said today.

DINGMAN'S FERRY, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) One person was killed and a truck driver was critically injured last night when a tanker truck crashed into an antique store, exploding into a ball of flame, the state police said.

Charles B. Eddy Jr., retired executive vice president of Chemical Bank, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 238 Old Short Hills Road, Short Hills, N.J.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that if he sought re-election next year he would run "all the way" even if he lost the New York State's Republican primary.

THE city fathers of Atlantic City announced not long ago that they would go before the state's Casino Control Commission to defend Resorts International's application for a permanent casino license. The reader of "House of Cards" will have no difficulty understanding what is afoot.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) The Marine Midland Bank branch on Route 17 here was robbed this morning, and the police took into custody a New Jersey man about 20 minutes later in Haverstraw. The town police in Haverstraw said they had arrested David Ruff, 46 years old, of Allendale, N.J. They said nearly $5,700 taken in the holdup was recovered.

The Grow Chemical Corporation said it had signed an agreement to purchase for an undisclosed amount an of the outstanding stock of the Trewax Company of Los Angeles, a manufacturer of chemicals and machines for the cleaning and maintenance of carpets, floors, furniture and automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 The Civil Aeronautics Board agreed today to order the airlines to provide wider separation between nonsmoking passengers and those who smoke pipes or cigars, and it set in motion a proceeding that could lead to a ban on pipe and cigar smoking on planes.

The stock market chalked up three winning sessions in a row for 1979 yesterday, with prices bolstered by a steady dollar in fore'gn-currency dealings and by reassurances from a Federal Reserve Board governor about the nation's troublesome trade deficit.

THE New Year starts on a high note at New York's top two auction galleries. The first sales of 1979 are of old masters, which are commanding far more serious attention by collectors, dealers and museums these days than at any other time since the 1930's. One reason for the interest is that many of the paintings coming up for sale have been hidden away for decades in collectors' homes or museum storage rooms.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 After years of controversy, California today effectively vetoed a Federal design for a billion-dollar dam on the American River near Sacramento, citing earthquake dangers.

DENVER, Jan. 4 When unions such as the United Automobile Workers or the United Steelworkers of America bargain on a national contract, they and their industry counterparts meet around a big table to work out their differences.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 When Governor Carey decided to use the 60 hours between the death of the 201st Legislature at midnight on Dec. 31 and the first rap of the gavel of the 202d Legislature to force his appointees into office without Senate re view, he expected some political fallout. He precipitated a heated battle instead.

The Rev. Jesse Jackson and three other leaders of the planned protest against the Kallie Knoetze bout in Miami Jan. 13 met yesterday with David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the president of Madison Square Garden, and with Frank Smith, the president of CBS Sports, in efforts to get both parties to forsake their roles in the bout. The Garden is co-promoting the fight, and CBS will televise it.

Thanks to two private gifts, the New York Public Library's Central Building at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue will extend its hours for the first time in three years, staying open until 9 P.M. three days a week.

Guillermo Vilas, who won the Australian open singles title on Wednesday, has decided to bypass the Grand Prix Masters tennis tournament next week at Madison Square Garden. His spot in the eight-player field will be filled by Arthur Ashe.

PEKING, Friday, Jan. 5 Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-Ping indicated today that China would probably not intervene in Cambodia to stop Vietnam's invasion, but he said Peking would support Cambodia's call for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on the incursion.

For the first time since the bitter winter of two years ago and for only the third time ever, American oil companies imported an average of more than 10 million barrels a day during a single week, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday in reporting its figures for the week ended Dec. 29.

Lucia Chase,the founding patron of American Ballet Theater and its artistic director during the company's rise to international status as a major American performing-arts group, will resign her position as director on Sept. 1,1980.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 Senator Edward M. Kennedy asked the Federal Trade Commission today to prohibit oil companies from owning pipelines and to order oil companies to divest themselves of pipelines they own now.
AUSTIN, Minn., Jan. 5 (UPI)-- Fire swept the three-story Ace Hotel on the city's east side today, killing four persons. They were not immediately identified.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 George Bush, former Director of Central Intelligence, filed with the Federal Election Commission today as a candidate for the Presidency but told reporters the move was just short of a formal declaration that he was running for the nomination.
ATLANTA, Jan. 5 (AP) Outbreaks of Russian flu have been confirmed in 10 states, with cases reported in five other states and in Puerto Rico, the National Center for Disease Control reported today.
MAJOR changes in the way life insurance is sold have made it easier than ever for individuals to buy coverage at cheap group rates through a variety of outlets.
TOKYO, Jan. 5 Japan's Ministry of Finance presented a budget proposal today for the next fiscal year equivalent to $200 billion.
H. Stern Jewelers, the Brazilian retailer with about 200 stores around the world, is expanding in New York City even though its Fifth Avenue store is only breaking even.

LLODIO, Spain, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Gunmen believed to be Basque guerrillas shot and seriously wounded a paramilitary Civil Guard in this northern Basque village today, police sources said. Members of the Basque nationalist group E.T.A. have killed three people this week.

Staten Island's Patrick J. Murphy was sworn in yesterday as chief of operations, the Police Department's highest uniformed post. As he pinned the gold badge on his jacket, Chief Murphy said, "I hope it doesn't fall off," to laughter from a roomful of police officials and members of his family.
BUFFALO, Jan. 5 Department heads in the administration of Mayor James D. Griffin have chipped in to send him and his wife, Margaret, to Miami for a week's vacation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 A Federal district judge in Virginia today approved a $518,000 damage award to a prisoner who charged that his permanent paralysis had been caused by improper treatment by doctors and other employees of the Virginia state prison system.
Vincent Korda, an Oscar-winning art director for motion pictures and a painter, died Thursday in London. He was 81 years old and lived in England and in Cap d'Antibes, France.

CULLMAN, Ala., Jan. 5 Three national civil rights organizations, vying for the right to represent a 27-year-old mentally retarded black man, Tommy Lee Hines, who was convicted of raping a white woman, agreed today on a chief counsel for the defendant.
Dr. Joseph T. Findaro, who lectured widely and wrote about the role of the pediatrician in sports, died yesterday morning after a short illness. He was 51 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

Each evening, Laura Taylor takes her 7year-old son, Tony, a second-grader at the Clinton School here, to the quiet of his bedroom and spends from 7 to 7:45 P.M. reviewing his homework, discussing his classroom assignments and helping him with his reading, which, Mrs. Taylor says, gives him some trouble.

The New York Rangers beat the Vancouver Canucks last night, 6-4, at Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League game that was part hockey and part brawl.

Bishop Francis J. Mugavero of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn yesterday gave $250 to the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 The Department of Energy sued nine of the nation's largest oil companies today, alleging that they had overcharged their customers by nearly $1 billion over the last five years for natural-gas liquids used in manufacturing home-heating fuels and other products.

William Stix Wasserman, a leading investment banker who was the chief of the United States lend-lease mission to Australia early in World War II, died yesterday of a coronary occlusion at his home at 895 Park Avenue. He was 77 years old and also had a home in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 (Reuters) Prime Minister Pol Pot of Cambodia said today that his people were engaged in a "life-or-death struggle" on five fronts against Vietnamese invaders and implied that the Cambodian forces had been forced to shift to guerrilla warfare.

NEWARK, Jan. 5 A spectacular four-alarm fire, punctuated by exploding drums of chemicals that sent fireballs hundreds of feet into the air, blazed out of control for almost seven hours during the night, leveling a one-story brick warehouse and halting traffic on Routes 1-9.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 5 A Federal district judge today refused a motion to dismiss a suit that contends that the Army Corps of Engineers is constructing the $2 billion Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway without proper authorization.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had discovered a new oilfield on its newly acquired Block 1-B in the Amazon Basin of Peru. The field is approximately 10 miles from one of Occidental's feeder pipelines and about 20 miles from the nearest producing field on Occidental's adjacent Block 1-A, acquired in 1971.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 Documents from the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation dealing with "highly sensitive" inquiries and raising allegations of illegal actions by F.B.I. informers were discovered in the rubble of the People's Temple outpost in Guyana last month after the mass deaths of the Rev. Robert H. Lounsbury, a lawyer who was active for many years in local and New York State politics, was found shot to death in his apartment at 244 East 48th Street in Manhattan yesterday.

PEKING, Jan. 5 (UPI) The United States Steel Corporation will help China develop one of the largest iron ore mining facilities in the world for "well over $1 billion," steel company sources said today, confirming a disclosure made last month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) Deputy Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti said today that he would make a recommendation to President Carter in 30 days on whether Patricia Hearst should be freed from prison.

Lois Nettleton has been cast as Dorothy Thompson in "Strangers," a new play by Sherman Yellen that will open in New York on March 4. The drama, directed by Arvin Brown, is based on Miss Thompson's romance with and marriage to Sinclair Lewis.

LONDON, Jan. 7 (UPI) John McEnroe and Peter Fleming, the young lions of American tennis, rallied today to defeat Ilie Nastase and Sherwood Stewart in four sets to capture the $200,000 world doubles championship in their first attempt.

One of the most unusual was a bottle of ice wine from Edmeades Vineyards in Mendocino County in California. Ice wine is created when the ripe grapes are frozen on the vine. The water in the grapes freezes and drops away, leaving only the essence of the fruit to be vinified.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 9--Buoyed by the increase in athletic budgets and the number of sports for women, voting delegates of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (A.I.A.W.) zeroed in today on refining the division structure set up yesterday. That three-division setup replaced the small college-large college system previously used.
A potential new public health hazard from hepatitis carriers in New York City schools is being watched by Federal officials because of possible national implications.
State health officials said yesterday that the bankrupt Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital in West Harlem faced imminent closing.

FOR some time now the television networks have been presenting shows that award prizes to the "best" performers in various categories, generally chosen in ways that would not necessarily gain the approval of the Honest Ballot Association.

LOS ANGELES IT has taken Eva Le Gallienne 80 years to become a motion-picture star. Miss Le Gallienne, who will turn 80 years old tomorrow, will leave her Connecticut country house for Los Angeles on Saturday to co-star with Ellen Burstyn and Sam Shepard in "Resurrection."

Jessie Williams Swift, who had been president of the Brooklyn Thoracic Hospital, now part of Brooklyn Hospital, from 1931 to 1947, died yesterday in a nursing home in Trumbull, Conn. She was 100 years old and had lived most of her life in Brooklyn Heights.

Only in America, or in Gilbert and Sullivan, could officers of state create a deadlock like the one Democratic Governor Hugh Carey and Republican Senator Warren Anderson devised for themselves last week.

YOU walk into a supermarket, looking for this week's crop of bargains. You know that Green Giant corn is advertised at 3 cans for $1. But the cans in the supermarket are clearly marked 37 cents. You pick up the corn, preparing for a battle at the checkout counter.

PEKING, Jan. 9--Teng Hsiao-ping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, said today that Taiwan could retain both its government and its armed forces and remain fully autonomous after it was reunified with the Chinese mainland.

SALEM, Ore., Jan. 10 (AP)--John and Greta Rideout, the couple involved in what was believed to be the first trial of a husband charged with raping his wife while they were living together, have told their lawyers that they have made up.

The parents of Elizabeth McFadden, the 11-year-old Long Island girl whose leg was reconnected by surgeons two weeks ago after it was severed by a Long Island Rail Road train, said they planned to sue the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for $7.5 million in damages.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 9 (UPI)--Ranking operations brought to a standstill for the last 20 days by employees demanding mom money left India's economy in chaos today.

In one of the biggest takeover attempts on record, the American Express Company, best known for its travelers' checks and credit cards, offered yesterday to pay $830 million in cash for McGraw-Hill Inc., one of the nation's largest publishers.

WHEN Yale University asked me to participate in its lecturer series this past term, I agreed in part be cause I thought the association might help redeem my undistinguished, indeed embarrassing, record as an undergraduate ...

The video disk competition warmed up several degrees yesterday with an announcement by the RCA Corporation that it "will proceed with maximum speed" to introduce its Selectavision system, in an effort to get in on the ground floor of a projected multibilliondollar industry.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 9--An elderly and ailing Latvian emigre, at a deportation hearing here today, confronted a former Latvian policeman whom she accuses of aiding Nazi executioners in 1941 by herding Jews to their deaths before a machine gun.

Chester Watson, a bass-baritone who sang with opera companies and other music groups in New York and other cities for many years, died in his sleep Monday at his home in Manhattan. Mr. Watson, who also was a voice teacher, was 65 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9--One year after it waged a long and loud internal struggle over the makeup of its major college football group, the National Collegiate Athletic Association quickly and quietly voted today to maintain its present Division I-A setup at 139 teams, including the eight Ivy League colleges.

LONDON--The Irish writer Conor Cruise O'Brien once remarked apropos Africa that when people do not understand any political situation, they try to explain it by an analogy: hence the misleading comparisons between Rhodesia and Vietnam.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9--Long considered both a symbol of national pride and a monument to inefficiency and corruption, Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, has surprised its many critics by rising to the challenge posed by the country's huge new oil discoveries.
ALBANY, Jan. 9--The Assembly Codes Committee today revived efforts to restore the death penalty in New York State as it approved a capital-punishment bill and sent it to the floor.

WASHINGTON--The collapse of Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge regime, which brought suffering, death and summary executions to Cambodia for nearly four years, is cause neither for mourning nor celebration, for it is tied to Vietnamese annexationism and imperialism.

Dr. H. Houston Merritt, a pioneer, neurologist and a co-developer of the antiepilepsy drug called Dilantin, died last night at the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. Dr. Merritt, a former dean of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, would have been 79 years old this week.

A new citywide reading examination to diagnose the academic deficiencies of 600,000 public-school children in New York City's elementary and junior high schools will be administered in October, Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 (AP)--A Federal appeals court to-day upheld a ruling that the Texas millionaire Nelson Bunker Hunt and his family were guilty of violating Government speculative limits on soybean trading.

WHEN the Knickerbocker Hotel opened on Times Square in 1906, 500 people were turned away from the dining rooms. "Where do all these people come from who fill up new hotels as fast as they are opened?" asked a news account at the time.

Pullman Inc. announced yesterday that Kellogg Continental B.V. Netherlands, an affiliate of its Pullman Kellogg division, had been awarded a contract by the China National Technical Import Corporation to provide advisory consulting, training and administrative services to the Chinese company. Terms were not disclosed.

Kallie Knoetze, the heavyweight boxer whose record as a constable in Pretoria provoked protests by antiapartheid groups here, yesterday became the first South African athlete barred from competition in this country when the State Department revoked his visa on grounds of "moral turpitude."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)--The Justice Department, as expected, asked a Federal court today to block the takeover of the American Investment Company by HFC American Inc., a subsidiary of the nation's largest independent finance company, the Household Finance Corporation.

MELILLA, Jan. 9 (Reuters)--The frontier police in this Spanish enclave on the North African coast said today that they had detained a 24-year-old New Yorker Arthur George Manchester, and seized 60 pounds of hashish. They said the drug, valued at almost $40,000 on the black market, was concealed in a false compartment of the gas tank in Mr. Manchester's Dutch-registered car.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's domination is more subtle these days. The 7-foot-2inch Los Angeles center showed his full maturity last night in the Lakers' 10694 victory over the Knicks before a crowd of 16,532 at Madison Square Garden.

THREE disco musicals are hustling for spring openings. Be cause record tie-ins with huge profit potentials are involved, the producers sound ready to resort to just about anything, even an old-fashioned rain dance, to speed things up and open ahead of the competition.

The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee, made up of the 12 governors and regional Federal Reserve Bank presidents who meet monthly to set monetary policy, will not hold a meeting in January but will convene next on Feb 6, a spokesman said yesterday.

Pier Luigi Nervi, the Italian engineer whose soaring, taut buildings of reinforced concrete are among the most dramatic structures 20th-century architecture has produced, died yesterday at his home in Rome. He was 87 years old.

SACRAMENTO, Jan. 9--After a second-term inaugural speech in which he staked his claim as the Democratic Party's fiscal conservative, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. said in an interview today that "it would be premature" to discuss whether he intended to challenge President Carter in 1980.

MADRID, Jan. 9--A savage campaign of terrorism by the Basque organization E.T.A., peaking just as the nation prepares for important elections, has strained relations between military and civilian authorities in Spain more than at ...
TEL AVIV, Jan. 9 (AP)--Eight prisoners, most of them convicted murderers and one a convicted Arab terrorist, escaped from an Israeli prison and are being sought, the authorities said today.

POINTE--A--PITRE, Guadeloupe, Jan. 9 (Reuters)--President Carter flew to Washington today after a five-day stay on this French Caribbean island. He arrived Thursday for talks with the leaders of France, Britain and West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A new report by the General Accounting Office contends that the Environmental Protection Agency inadequately monitors, inaccurately reports and ineffectively enforces the nation's basic law on air pollution.
TRENTON, Jan. 9--Following are excerpts from the State of the State message Governor Byrne delivered to the joint session of the Legislature today:
Neal Heaton was a Met fan once. He says he's still a Met fan, but now he likes the Yankees more. "You don't like cheering on a losing team," he said.

Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger, signaling a major shift in the Administration's energy policy, said yesterday that the United States would emphasize increased industrial consumption of natural gas, instead of coal, to reduce oil imports.

The Maroczy Bind, a formation of pawns at QB4 and K4 as against the opponent's center pawn at Q3, is usually set up by White because it takes time for pawn moves and therefore lets piece mobilization lag.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9--Muscovites, who are among the world's most creative rumormongers, worked themselves into a new frenzy of fantasy last week as they spread the word that the capital was headed for a cold snap that would make the record low of 35.8 degrees below zero Fahrenheit the previous weekend feel like a breath of spring.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Jan. 9 (Reuters)--Stepan Bilandzic, a Croatian exile, will go on trial here tomorrow on charges of having supplied weapons for use against the Yugoslav Government.
OF course, you know that black pepper is the most widely used spice in the United States today. But if you were to haz ard a guess as to the second ranking spice, the chances are that you'd be wrong.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 9--On its first working day in office, Iran's new Government found itself immobilized today by opposition from most sectors of the society.

Bernard King, the New Jersey Nets' high-scoring forward, stood silently in Brooklyn Criminal Court yesterday as his attorney, Robert Hill Schwartz, entered pleas of not guilty to charges of driving while intoxicated, criminal possession of a controlled substance and driving without a license.
IS this the food of the future? Pizza with fabricated pepperoni and analog mozzarella, polyunsaturated prime ribs of beef with high-C mashed potatoes; imitation caviar and sauteed soft-shell lobster?

At least three children died in a fire that swept through a private house late last night in the Kew Gardens Hills area of Flushing, Queens, the Fire Department said. Five children were injured, and firemen were searching for more bodies.

At a Business Week staff meeting last spring, one of the magazine's reporters is said to have asked Harold W. McGraw Jr., chairman of McGrawHill, whether his company would consider a merger offer. Mr. McGraw, the story goes, said that an offer in the mid$30's range--more than 50 percent higher than the stock price at the time --might swing the family.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (AP)-- Bill Walsh was named head coach of the San Francisco 49ers today, becoming the fifth man to hold the job since Edward DeBartolo Jr. bought the team 22 months ago.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 (UPI)-- The Pacific Telephone Company said today that it would spend $2 billion on capital construction in 1979, a record amount.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The main problem of United States foreign policy in 1979, as Secretary of State Vance sees it, is to hold a fair balance in Washington's East-West relations, and particularly to hold the Western alliance together and somehow maintain an even-handed policy toward both China and the Soviet Union.

NADAILLAC-LE-SEC, FRANCE Gloom has settled on this valley in Perigord as farmers contemplate a poor harvest of one of the area's most famous delicacies, the truffle. It appears that this year, following a summer drought, there will be only four tons of truffles, about half of last years's crop, causing prices to double to a staggering $250 a pound in Paris and $384 in New York.
Widespread expectations that the Administration was preparing new anti-inflation and dollar-support measures provoked moderate selling of futures contracts in precious metals yesterday.

DENVER, Jan. 9--Top officials of the Government's mediation service flew to Denver today in an effort to head off a confrontation between the oil companies and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union, whose bargaining over a new contract poses the first test of President Carter's 7 percent wage-restraint program.

An elderly "shopping bag lady" who has spent the last two months in the Presbyterian Hospital was identified yesterday as Hungarian-born Julia Simon, one of the legion of homeless, independent, often eccentric women who live on the city's streets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The Republican National Committee announced today that it had decided to put off its plan to raise money by promoting Visa credit cards and would join the Democrats in asking the Federal Election Commission if the project was legal.
Mohammed Riza Pahlevi may be losing a kingdom in Iran, but the pain of his exile, if and when it comes, will be considerably eased by one of the largest private fortunes in the world.
Ogden M. (Dinny) Phipps, the chairman of the New York Racing Association, joined Affirmed and Seattle Slew yesterday as the winner of an Eclipse Award.

With price gains in acquisition targets providing part of the sparkle, the stock market resumed its winning ways yesterday. Trading volume expanded on the upswing that produced more than 1,000 advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--By a 6-to-3 vote, the Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Pennsylvania law that required a doctor performing an abortion to choose the abortion method most likely to save the life of a fetus that might be old enough to survive outside the womb.

TRENTON, Jan. 9--Governor Byrne told the Legislature in his annual State of the State message today that New Jersey's resources would not allow for major new programs, but he called for a shift in state aid formulas to provide extra financial help for distressed cities.

Advertisements in local daily newspapers today offer a reward of up to 10 percent for information leading to the recovery of property or currency seized at the Lufthansa Airlines area at Kennedy International Airport Dec. 11. The robbers got approximately $5 million in unmarked United States currency and almost $1 million in jewelry.

Emil Martini Jr., chairman of the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, said that second-quarter operating earnings would "be substantially above a year ago" and that if the trend continued for the year "there is a strong possibility of a dividend increase."
TOKYO, Jan. 10 (AP)--Two Mitsubishi companies have established a joint venture to develop uranium deposits in New Mexico with the Getty Oil Company, a spokesman said today.
Thurman Munson, the New York Yankees' catcher, will undergo surgery on his right shoulder in Los Angeles tomorrow, the club announced yesterday.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- The Ohio Senate adopted today a resolution honoring Woody Hayes for his "many years of dedicated service" to Ohio State University.

The American International Group said it had revised the terms of its merger proposal with the Mission Insurance Group because Mission was unable to meet one A.I.G. condition-- that Mission not agree to sell 606,000 of its shares to the American Financial Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, has called inadequate the proposals by the Federal Communications Commission to increase the number of radio stations in the country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Zale Corporation, the country's largest retail jeweler, is the subject of a widespread criminal tax investigation by the Internal Revenue Service, which says that the company and its subsidiaries may owe more than $100 million in back taxes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Two Republican members of Congress, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, announced today that they would again sponsor a bill to cut taxes by 30 percent over the next three years and would offer a companion measure to limit increases in Government spending.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will receive Prince Norodom Sihanouk if the former head of state of Cambodia asks for an appointment, a State Department spokesman said today.

LONDON, Jan. 10--The city swung last night at a nonstop party that raised a few pence for UNICEF, marked the opening of Regine's spectacular rooftop club in the West End and, for a few hours, recaptured some of the mad extravagance reminiscent of the swinging 1960's. The town hadn't seen anything quite like it for a long time.

BONN, Jan. 10 (Reuters)--President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia flew home today after more than two months in a hospital here, a Tunisian Embassy spokesman said. The spokesman had no details of the President's condition, but embassy sources said his health was restored. They said Mr. Bourguiba had suffered mainly from disturbed sleep.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10--Accusing the National Collegiate Athletic Association of having insulted Congress, Representative James Santini, Democrat of Nevada, said today that he would press for more Congressional hearings into the operation of the N.C.A.A. He indicated that new hearings might explore whether or not the N.C.A.A. is in violation of antitrust laws in the way it awards television contracts and restricts TV appearances by member institutions.

OTTAWA, Jan. 10--Canada's largest consumer group, which has been fighting the country's largest utility over its rate structure, has had to go to Washington to obtain information it has been unable to get in Ottawa.

HARTFORD THE ideas in Alice Childress's "Wedding Band" are like wildflowers growing in their own ground; not, as in works of less art, like cut flowers sorted and offered by the dozen at a florist shop.
Declines in soybean prices highlighted the trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. The downward move came at a time when high prices have dominated traders' thinking.

The Louisville Gas and Electric Company, a largely coal-based utility that serves north-central Kentucky, priced an offering of one million shares of common stock late yesterday at $21 a share, the closing price on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock, which yields 9.50 percent, is being sold through a group led by the First Boston Corporation.

Dr. Clifford Barbour, a former Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, died yesterday at the University of Tennesee Hospital in Knoxville. He was 83 years old and had lived in Maryville, Tenn.

With the sound of an approaching train in his ears, a Transit Authority policeman jumped to the tracks early yesterday morning, hopped over the third rail and scooped up a 14-year-old boy who had tumbled there when pursued by a mugger in a Brooklyn subway station.
A puzzling haze over the Arctic ice packs has been identified as a byproduct of air pollution, a finding that may support predictions of a disastrous melting of the earth's ice caps.

Colt Industries' earnings increased 20.6 percent in the fourth quarter and 25 percent for all 1978, mostly as a result of strong performances by fluid control systems, industrial seals and components.
J.P. Morgan Company, parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, yesterday announced a 21.9 percent jump in fourth-quarter operating earnings and a 22.2 percent gain for 1978.
The accounting profession's rulemaking board proposed yesterday that the nation's larger companies be required to report the effect of inflation on their operations.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Jan. 9--Pat Vecchio is cutting downfield on the Gracie Mansion lawn with a football under his arm and with John V. Lindsay blocking for him and still managing the smile that is the same in games as it is on posters.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 10 (AP)--Ernest Graham scored a game-high 24 points, including a turnaround jumper with seven seconds left in the second overtime tonight, to give Maryland an 82-81 upset victory over eighth-ranked North Carolina State in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--Retail sales increased by 1 percent last month, according to Government figures released today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 10--A Chilean Army colonel wanted by the United States to stand trial for the assassination in Washington of Orlando Letelier has been temporarily freed to hand over command of his regiment in a military ceremony.

LUXOR, Egypt--A wizened peasant sidled up to an American tourist strolling along the main street of this resort in Upper Egypt and furtively unrolled a tattered newspaper to display a small pharaonic carving. He pointed across the Nile to the yellow hills of the Theban necropolis and, his free hand making chopping motions, whispered in English, "Only 10 pounds!"

The dollar slid in New York yesterday after the Carter Administration said it planned no announcement soon on new dollar-support measures. Rumors that the Government would shortly take steps to further strengthen the dollar had spurred it to a good performance against most currencies overseas.

Stockholders of the American Home Products Corporation, responding to urgent pleas from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, have voluntarily returned 98 percent of the $7.8 million that the bank's computer erroneously paid in dividends.

STOCK market analysts often find attraction in historically low price-earnings ratios and in high dividend yields. The trouble with these and other traditional measures is that they compare apples with oranges, or as Austin S. Donnelly puts it, "cricket and baseball."
The administration of Mayor Koch wants the State Legislature to increase New York City's welfare grants for the first time since 1974 and to assume the full extra cost.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--New York State today issued a plan for meeting Federal air standards in the New York City area that is markedly less stringent than one proposed in 1973.

Resorts International is now responding to charges before the New Jersey Casino Commission that it is unfit to run a gambling casino. Resorts opened its Atlantic City gambling palace last May under a temporary license. Since then it has averaged profits of $600,000 a day, about $48,000 of which goes to the state and is allocated to programs for the elderly.

Almost unnoticed in 1978, a year that produced such top rookies as Nancy Lopez in golf and John McEnroe in tennis, was ski racing's Andre Arnold, a shy house painter from the small Austrian resort town of Solden.
Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe provided a preview of coming attractions last night with impressive straight-set victories in the Grand Prix Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 10 (UPI)-- The Colombian Government has suspended operations of The Associated Press, accusing the news agency of failing to have the proper accreditation and transmitting "frankly tendentious and inexact" news. The presidential press office said today that A.P. had no representative registered with the Communications Ministry or any authorities, as required, and would be suspended until it met the requirements.

The Board of Ethics reaffirmed yesterday its position that a former New York City official now employed by one of the two companies competing for the city's lucrative bus-shelter franchise was not involved in a conflict of interest.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 10--The central committee of the World Council of Churches voted today to continue a controversial program that grants aid to militant political groups but tempered its support by including a provision that is intended to give the program's critics a stronger voice.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Coach Earle Bruce of Iowa State University appears to be the man Ohio State has settled on to replace Woody Hayes.

The Hudson Pulp and Paper Corporation announced that the closing of the merger of Hudson with a subsidiary of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation had been postponed, pending the clarification of certain tax matters relating to the merger. The closing had been scheduled for yesterday. Hudson added that the closing of the merger was expected to take place shortly.

SUGGESTIONS,' which Harry Streep 3d's Third Dance Theater offered at the American Theater Laboratory on Tuesday evening, was the sort of work in which first, the first thing happened. Then the second thing happened--but for no apparent reason. It was simply the second thing that happened.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Council on Wage and Price Stability closed a loophole today by modifying its 7 percent standard for pay increases. The council said that a Minneapolis company ...
BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10--Vietnamese troops driving westward in Cambodia were fighting in the town of Siem Reap, near the temple complex at Angkor, Western analysts reported today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10-- The 15 nations represented on the United Nations Security Council agreed tonight to convene a formal meeting tomorrow afternoon to consider the Cambodian crisis.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Environmental Protection Agency proposed today strict emission standards for diesel-powered engines, and General Motors reacted almost immediately by expressing concern that the proposals could ban large diesel-powered autos.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Taiwan had a trade surplus of $1.68 billion in 1978, up from $849.8 million in 1977, the Government reported today. The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said exports last year rose 35.7 percent to $12.7 billion, while imports rose 29.5 percent to $11.02 billion.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 10 (AP)--A Federal district judge today ordered dissident steel haulers to end a violent nineweek strike and threatened to jail the group's leaders if the order was ignored. But the steel haulers immediately appealed the decision and said the strike would continue.

TRENTON, Jan. 10--Responding to the emotional pleas of 300 Newark teachers, parents and students who came here seeking to avert 1,100 scheduled layoffs in the city's deficit-ridden school system, the State Commissioner of Education today promised to assume increased control of the district's financial affairs, but said he had no power to rescind the layoffs set for Friday.

LATE 1978: Magazine assignment--positive approach to love in 1979. How foolishly perfect that I will miss the deadline because of him. But then what drives writing forward if not obsession, and what better obsession than love? Except the obsession of this love is fighting, although when even tension becomes a ritual the glamour pales.
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.
A second gift on behalf of the New York Rangers and the New York Knickerbockers has been received by the 67th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

TOKYO, Jan. 10--The Toyota organization expects to sign a contract to assemble two-ton trucks in Peking and thus become the first foreign automobile manufacturer to enter the new China market, Seishi Kato, president of Toyota Motor Sales, said today.

PEKING, Jan. 10--In Chinese chess, the object is not to directly capture an opponent's pieces, but to gradually surround and isolate them. This strategy of avoiding a costly frontal assault and instead subtly undermining the enemy is also a basic precept of traditional Chinese statecraft.

GENEVA, Jan. 10--Switzerland's financial authorities confirmed today that top priority would be given this year to a liberal monetary policy aimed at curbing the upward pressures on the Swiss franc in foreign currency markets.

ALTHOUGH until last June she hadn't worked a day of her life in an agency media deparatment, Marcella Rosen is now not only the media director of N.W. Ayer ABH International but also possibly the world's top-ranking women in the field.

Cargill Inc. announced that its wholly owned subsidiary, Cargill Holdings Inc., now owned or had under contract about 89.5 percent of the MBPXL Corporation common stock. Cargill Holdings said it had extended its tender offer for any and all shares of MBPXL common stock at $27 a share until Jan. 22. The offer was originally scheduled to expire Jan. 8.

IT'S always been my perverse pleasure, before throwing out gift catalogues at the holidays' end, to thumb through them for a last time, rejoicing at the gifts I didn't get --the ones that, thank God, nobody had the will or the money to bestow upon me.

STOCKHOLM, Jan. 10 (Reuters)-- A 20-year agreement that allows Sweden regular oil supplies from Norway will fail if Norway is unable to take a 40 percent stake in Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, Bjartmar Gjerde, the Norwegian Energy Minister, said today.

BOSTON, Jan. 10--The State of Massachusetts sold $1 million worth of five-year, tax-exempt "minibonds" yesterday directly to the public in denominations of $100, $500 and $1,000. The issue promptly sold out.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 10--The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company adequately informed stockholders of product liability problems with its steel-belted radial tires in 1976 and 1977.
DENVER, Colo., Jan. 10--The New York Rangers got high-scoring Don Murdoch back in uniform for the first time this season tonight, then went out and proved they didn't need him--at least for one game.

"IF you can't draw a straight line," Paulus Berensohn advised, "draw a crooked line and draw it over and over again." And to prove how easy it is, Mr. Berensohn used the crooked line as the starting point in the singular designs of his needlepoint and bargello tapestries on exhibition at Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, until Jan. 27.

NEW PROVIDENCE, N.J.--On May 14, 1973, the world's first orbiting space station, Skylab, was launched. Three crews lived, worked and conducted experiments in Skylab. It was a remarkable achievement, proving that man can live and work in space for an extended period of time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Administration's chief inflation adviser, Alfred E. Kahn, ran into opposition from urban leaders today when he told them the country could not now afford to reduce unemployment and rebuild the cities.

MUNICH, West Germany THE tenor with the Metropolitan Opera Company who walked out on the lead role in the season's opening-night program and then, without explanation, turned his back on what he described as more than $500,000 in contracts with the Met, leaned forward and finally told what happened.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 10 (AP) --Moslem guerrillas report gains in their battle against Afghanistan's Sovietbacked Government but say they are short of supplies and are hampered by rough terrain, bad weather and internal conflicts.

The Sandgate Corporation disclosed that it was having preliminary discussions with an unrelated company listed on the New York Stock Exchange concerning the possible aquisition of Sandgate in exchange for shares of the other company.

Robert Simpson, vice president in the international division of the Chemical Bank, died Tuesday at Doctors Hospital in New York, after a long illness. He was 57 years old and lived at 141 East 88th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The United States economy "is out of step with the rest of the world" and should grow more slowly than the economies of other countries this year, the Bank of America's chief economist said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--Sometimes a change of circumstances can illuminate a historical truth. The Vietskreig--Vietnam's lightning takeover of Cambodia--is one of those changes.
YOU have your fantasy of Lauren Bacall and I have mine, and heaven forbid that they be tampered with; it's so rare that interesting people come to call at the sound of a whistle.
The Rorer Group and Narco Scientific Inc. announced jointly that the directors of both companies had approved an agreement in principle to merge Narco into Rorer.
HAVING ushered in the new year with prophecies about the future of audio, let us further pursue the hot topic of digital recording upon which this future unquestionably hinges.

Katherine Durham, who electrified Broadway audiences in the 1930's and 40's with her primitive-dance revues, will be honored in a gala benefit to be held at Carnegie Hall on Monday, Martin Luther King Day.

The Federal National Mortgage Association, the Government-sponsored company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday reported from Washington that fourth-quarter net income rose 15.6 percent to $51.1 million, or 91 cents a share, from $44.2 million, or 82 cents a share, for the 1977 final quarter.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 10--A thousand police officers poured into this small North Jersey community to pay homage to Joseph J. Rybka Jr., the Bergen County sheriff's officer slain early Sunday while guarding a hospitalized burglary suspect. He was eulogized today for "dying in service to his community and county."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Federal Reserve Board acted today to discourage banks from offering distant customers special services that deliberately delay the clearing of their checks.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10--If Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. decides to make a run for the Democratic Presidential nomination next year, it appears that he can do it from a reasonably secure power base in California.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Treasury Department today ordered special duties on imports of bicycle tires and tubes from a South Korean manufacturer. The Treasury declined to act against other manufacturers on the ground that the subsidies they received from the Seoul Government were insignificant. The major American maker of bicycle tires and tubes, the Carlisle Rubber and Tube Company of Carlisle, Pa., had said that it was injured by the imports.
ROCHESTER, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Eastman Kodak Company has halted the production and marketing of sound movie cameras.

ARTURO Benedetti Michelangeli may never be heard again in person by the Ameri can public for various reasons concerned with the Italian pianist's eccentricities. It makes interest in him all that much greater and the release of any new recordings by him that much more welcome.
CHICAGO, Jan. 10--John Wayne Gacy stood quietly in a heavily guarded Cook County courtroom here today as his lawyer entered a not guilty plea for him in seven murder indictments.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 10 (AP) --The State of New Jersey was ordered yesterday to pay for medically necessary abortions for poor women.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 10--Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar was quoted today as having said that Iran faces the danger of a military coup but that he still expects the Shah to leave the country.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (Reuters) The Chicago Art Institute today doubled its reward to $100,000 for the recovery of three paintings by Cezanne. The paintings, valued at $3 million, disappeared last month from a locked storeroom.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 12 Tribal raiders from Nagaland, a northeastern state of India, have massacred at least 50 people in attacks on 10 villages in the neighboring state of Assam.

Hefner, head of the multimillion-dollar Playboy empire, and his 26-year-old daughter, Christie, a company vice president, have evolved into one of the nation's better-known father-daughter business teams. He has designated her his heir apparent or, as some wags put it, his "hare apparent."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, has asked the Senate ethics committee to exclude from its trial-like inquiry into his financial affairs documentary evidence turned over by his chief accuser, according to sources close to the investigation.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the four major domestic automobile companies, will no longer publicly disclose its 10-day sales results, abandoning a practice prevalent in the automobile industry for decades.

Jimmy Connors was out of the tournament. Tenderly favoring a blistered and bloodied left foot, he had surrendered while trailing John McEnroe, 7-5, 3-0, in their Grand Prix Masters singles match Thursday night.

KITTERY, Me., Jan. 12 (AP) A national expert in radiation illness has quit a team assigned to investigate cancer at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard because the Government refused to grant him full access to Navy data.
New York City's Conciliation and Appeals Board has ruled that the management of Lincoln Towers apartments overcharged new tenants as much as $150 a month in rent over the last 18 months.

Texas Commerce Bancshares, parent of the Texas Commerce Bank in Houston, yesterday became the latest bank holding company to report a hefty gain in operating earnings for 1978 and the final quarter of the year.
Dr. Murray Israel, an internist, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 President Carter dismissed Bella S. Abzug today as co-chairman of his National Advisory Committee on Women after an angry exchange with the former New York Representative at a White House meeting on women's issues.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 Volkswagen of America today announced price increases averaging 3.9 percent for its new cars after becoming the first foreign-owned company to submit a pricing decision for scrutiny by President Carter's Council on Wage and Price Stability.

NEWARK, Jan. 12 A Superior Court judge's ruling today that the Newark Board of Education's dismissal of more than 1,100 employees last month was invalid has averted a strike by more than 8,000 teachers and school employees scheduled for Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 The Carter Administration said today that it had encountered problems in its plan to send a squadron of fighter planes to Saudi Arabia later this month because the Spanish Government refuses to allow the planes to land and refuel at an American-run base in Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 A three-year lobbying effort by New York City was rebuffed today when the Carter Administration decided to establish a new national fire academy in rural Maryland and not on Wards and Randalls Islands in the East River.
DETROIT, Jan. 12 (AP) Auto assemblies this week will jump 20.8 percent from last week's holiday-shortened schedule, a trade publication says.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 12 (AP) Fourth Street Elementary School has been renamed the Golda Meir Elementary School in honor of the former Israeli Prime Minister who died Dec. 8. Mrs. Meir once attended the school.

Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that the police had arrested a wrong man when they took into custody five Borough Park residents last Monday in connection with demonstrations by Jewish residents of the area at the 66th Precinct station house in Brooklyn last month.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (UPI) The Philadelphia City Council has been ordered by a judge to sign by Jan. 19 a contract for the construction of the Whitman Park Townhouse project.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 12 The Internal Revenue Service has begun an investigation of the political activities of the People's Temple that, sources said, could lead to a revocation of the Temple's taxexempt status and a claim for back taxes amounting possibly to millions of dollars.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 12 (AP) John Mahaffey retained the lead with a round of 71, but Lee Trevino, experimenting with a new putting technique, moved into strong contention today in the third round of the $275,000 Desert Golf Classic.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 12 Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar said today that Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi would leave Iran within a week, visit a country in the Middle East or Europe and then spend most of the rest of his time abroad in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) The National Steel Corporation agreed today to pay $3.5 million in fines and to install $21.6 million worth of water pollution control equipment at its plant in Weirton, W.Va.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12 (AP) Members of Local 610 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted today to ratify contracts that will end a series of strikes that have shut down the city's two major papers for more than seven weeks.

New York City's offtrack betting operation has not paid off as promised when it was started in 1971. Instead of $100 million a year, the city's take has been only about $60 million, and bookmakers, although still illegal, seem to have lost few customers.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 (Reuters) A former leader of a Japanese Communist guerrilla group was sentenced today to four years in prison for his role in a 1970 airline hijacking. ALL spacecraft orbit something--usually Earth or the Sun, and sometimes the Moon and planets. For the first time, however, there is a spacecraft between Earth and the Sun that appears to be orbiting nothing. It is circling a libration point, a point in space where the opposing gravitational forces of two large bodies (the Sun and Earth, in this case) are exactly counterbalanced.

When a foreigner reading the broadside wondered aloud how the dispute would be resolved, a Chinese onlooker responded jocularly, "Let them go see God --he can settle it." "No," said another bystander, "Go see Marx. He knows the answer to everything."

New York City's sale of $125 million of short-term notes to the public is an important first step in the city's financial recovery, city officials said yesterday, but they pointed out that it did not mean the fiscal crisis was over.

Corporate takeover stocks, which produced many of Wall Street's big winners last year, continued to shine yesterday, along with two prominent glamour issues. Elsewhere, the market generally showed small price changes in light trading.

The scheduled 8 percent return on the city's new note issue is the equivalent of about 12 percent to investors in the 50 percent tax bracket and carries a higher yield than anything of comparable maturity in the tax-exempt market.

TOKYO, Jan. 22 (UPI)--The Isuzu Motor Company, an affiliate of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it planned to cooperate in the production of small trucks in China. Toshio Okamoto, president, said at a news conference that his company would send a mission to China in February at the earliest to study a proposed plan. He said China planned to turn out about 10,000 1.5-ton and 2.5-ton trucks annually in Nanking.
BONN, Jan. 22 (Reuters)--West German television stations and buildings used by Jewish groups were under guard today to prevent bomb attacks during the telecast of "Holocaust."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--The rumors started spreading in midNovember: President Carter's budget for 1980 would cut deeply into spending for higher education. By early December a copy of the budget had leaked out and the rumors were confirmed. One program, National Direct Student Loans, would be "zeroed out," dropped entirely.

But the Transportation Department advised the C.A.B. to approve both of them and let the applicants bid against each other for National's stock.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22--The proposed new Defense Department budget of $122.7 billion represents an increase of slightly more than 3 percent, adjusted for inflation, over that of the current fiscal year. It stresses combat readiness in Europe and modernizing of the nuclear forces.

Sometimes the outlays occur over a period of years, as when the Defense Department places an order for a warship.

Directors of the American Express Company, following a regular monthly meeting yesterday, released a statement affirming their unanimous intention to proceed with their merger offer for McGraw-Hill Inc. and backing the actions taken by their company's management in making the offer.

QUICK, what was your total food bill in 1978? Although most of us would be hard pressed even to pull a figure from the air, the City of New York Department of Consumer Affairs reports that a typical family of four spent $4,252.28 on groceries last year. That's 10.8 percent above 1977 costs, with only two items actually going down in price: carrots and coffee.

THE most striking piece on Jo seph Fuchs's violin recital pro gram Monday night at Carnegie Hall was Ralph Vaughan Williams's "Concerto Accademico" in D Minor (1925). ROME, Jan. 23 (Reuters)--Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met with Italian officials today for talks expected to bring about agreements on scientific, cultural and legal cooperation between Italy and the Soviet Union.
CAIRO, Jan. 23--The Shah of Iran has accepted an invitation from President Anwar el-Sadat to take up residence in Cairo after his current visit to Morocco, it was reported today.

Connors won by 6-4, 6-3 at the Spectrum before 8,392 fans.

The 1980 Democratic Presidential campaign has begun and, at first blush, it looked as if Jerry Brown had stolen the march on Jimmy Carter. The California Governor's second inaugural address, with its call for a constitutional amendment to balance the Federal budget, stirred public imagination.
THE constantly growing cat food market, which is expected to hit the magic $1 billion in retail sales this year, is getting at least four new products in the hottest segment of the market, dry food.

For half a century following the famous cruise during which Vanderbilt codified contract bridge, every world title, with one minor exception, was won by players from Europe and North America. But the picture has changed completely since 1975: Brazil has emerged as a major power in the bridge world.

A Brooklyn homicide detective shot and killed a 29-year-old murder suspect last night when he mistakenly thought the man was pulling a gun on him, the police said.

Robert Requena scored 22 points and Larry Vitelli had 17 to lead Brooklyn College to a 71-60 victory yesterday over Lehman College in a City University Conference game at the loser's court. Keith Yearwood of Lehman led all scorers with 24 points. Brooklyn's overall record is now 6-9 and 2-2 in the conference. Lehman is 4-10 over all and 1-4 in the conference.

Two coaches, Bill Hodges of Indiana State and Dean Smith of North Carolina, insisted on Saturday--perhaps too vehemently--that they did not think the No. 1 ranking in the wild, woolly world of college basketball was much to treasure in the middle of the long winter season.

Supporters of the controversial plan of New York's Board of Regents prescribing stiff new competency tests for all high school seniors by 1981 argue that the credibility of the high school diploma must be restored. SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 28 (AP)--A 27-year-old woman is surgically sterilized, then discovers a few months later that she is pregnant. She is divorced, with four children and no savings.

PARIS, Jan. 28 (AP)--High Echelon, an 85-1 shot, went ahead in the last 50 yards today and captured the $235,000 Prix d'Amerique trotting classic at Vincennes Race Track.

New orders for machine tools reached a record high $4.29 billion last year, up 43 percent from $2.99 billion in 1977. Orders in December fell from November's high level, but were up from year-earlier totals.

PONTIAC, Mich., Jan. 28 (AP)-- Detroit, behind torrid second-half shooting by Kevin Porter and John Long, broke the N.B.A. record for field goal percentage in one game in a 128 118 triumph over San Diego today. It was the Piston's fourth straight victory.
BEECH AIRCRAFT, a pioneer in building private planes, had a bumpy journey in the stock market last week as takeover rumors made the rounds once again.
Keeping to tradition, Columbia University Law School has chosen a faculty member, Prof. Albert J. Rosenthal, to be its new dean.

SAN ANTONIO, Jan. 28--There is an atmosphere of madness in the HemisFair Arena when the San Antonio Spurs walk onto the floor. The piped-in fiddles play "Cotton-Eyed Joe," the foot-stomping anthem of south Texas.
Kwei-sang Wang, a newspaperman and publishing executive in Chinatown, died of heart attack Friday at his home in Upper Montclair, N.J. He was 59 years old.
KANSAS CITY, Jan. 28 (AP)--Otis Birdsong scored 30 points and had 10 assists today to pace the Kansas City Kings to a 137-109 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28 (AP)-- Reggie Carter tallied 11 of his 13 points in the second half and sparked St. John's to a 47-40 victory over St. Joseph's today.

Several foreign companies raised the prices of their metals last week. The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company and Cominco Ltd. raised zinc prices in Canada by 2 cents a pound Hudson Bay also increased its price for the metal in the United States by 1 cent a pound.

TEHERAN, Iran, Monday, Jan. 29-- Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar's peace initiative collapsed yesterday less than 24 hours after it was announced, and violence erupted once more in the heart of Teheran.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 28--State environmental officials told a rare Saturday meeting of the Town Council yesterday that mercury contamination here posed no immediate health hazard, and they continued to reject demands from local officials for quick action against the pollution here and in the nearby Hackensack Meadowlands.

After more than a month of publicity and explanations for the Administration's decision to establish full diplomatic relations with China, a substantial plurality of the American people still disapproves of recognizing Peking at the expense of relations with Taiwan, according to the latest New York Times-CBS news poll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--A 79-yearold woman in Tennessee has, over the last 29 years, purchased and kept in force 30 insurance policies with five different companies. The cost, $98.85 a month, represents 55 percent of her meager welfare income.
The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly "Lotto" drawing were 32, 13, 21, 35, 2 and 30. The supplementary number was 18.

ALBANY--There is not much work in New York State by Henry Hobson Richardson, the immense, rotund and energetic man who was perhaps the greatest American architect of the 19th century.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28--Julie Andrews has just been signed by Universal to co-star with Walter Matthau in "Little Miss Marker," the third remake of the movie that made Shirley Temple a star in 1934.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan 28--John Williamson wouldn't let the New Jersey Nets die today. Scoring 16 of their last 23 points in the final 4 minutes 31 seconds, the man whom his teammates call Super John rallied the Nets to a 117114 victory over the Phoenix Suns at the Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

AMMAN, Jordan, Jan. 28 (Reuters)-- Former President Gerald R. Ford and his wife, Betty, left the Red Sea port of Aqaba today after a three-day visit to Jordan, where Mr. Ford held talks with King Hussein on the Middle East and other matters. The Fords are on a private tour of the Middle East.

The white House denied yesterday that the Carter Administration had conducted a campaign to undermine Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, as was reported in an article in the The New York Times Magazine on Jan. 21.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28--The Department of Justice has recommended that President Carter exert executive clemency and commute the sentence of Patricia Hearst, the publishing heiress who was convicted of participating in a 1974 armed bank robbery, key Administration sources said today.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 28 (Reuters)--Afghan dissidents are seeking arms from Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries to help their insurrection against the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul, informed sources said today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28--Ten years after the oil well blowout at Santa Barbara, the picturesque resort community of Spanish-style buildings and gleaming beaches has largely regained its traditional serenity.

The marriage of Susan Lynn Bloom, an associate counsel with New York State United Teachers, to Laurence Baron Jones, a lawyer with the New York firm of Winer, Neuburger Sive, took place yesterday at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Norton Shargel performed the ceremony.

The Libyan National Oil Company has informed several of its minor customers that they can expect their oil supplies to be curtailed starting Feb. 1. The communique cited "technical reasons" for a production shortfall.

After a yearlong nationwide search, the Ford Foundation yesterday named Franklin A. Thomas, a lawyer and one of New York City's most prominent blacks, to be its next president.

ROME, Jan. 29--Against a background of increasing political terrorism, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti went be fore Parliament today to defend the record of his 10-month-old Government, insisting that it was a success despite its loss of majority support. He is expected to resign tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Former President Richard M. Nixon returned to the White House tonight for the first time since his tearful farewell on Aug. 9, 1974, as he resigned the Presidency under threat of impeachment.

IN one way, the Pentagon Brass Quintet, which appeared Jan. 21 at Carnegie Recital Hall, was a throwback to earlier centuries when composer and performer tended to be the same person. A page from Teng Hsiao-ping's briefing book for an American visit: Money--The basic unit of American currency is the dollar. It is worth four packs of chewing gum.

BOSTON, Jan. 29--Relations between members of the first faculty union to gain a foothold at a major private university and one of the nation's most outspoken college presidents continued to deteriorate today as Boston University officials laid down the battle lines for what could be a long strike.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Jan. 29 (AP)--The second announced underground nuclear test of the year is scheduled for Wednesday at the Nevada Test Site, the Department of Energy said today. The weaponsrelated test will have a yield of from 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT, a department spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)--The Justice Department and the Transportation Department opposed the merger of Continental Air Lines and Western Airlines in separate papers sent to the Civil Aeronautics Board today.
SYRACUSE, Jan. 29 (AP)--Dale Shackleford, Syracuse's senior captain, scored 27 points to lead the Orangemen to a 90-74 victory over West Virginia in college basketball tonight.

Henry L. Duncombe Jr. retires this month at the age of 65 as vice president and chief economist of the General Motors Corporation after 22 years. But, more than just a leading economist with a staff of 35 professionals, Mr. Duncombe is a symbol. He was the first economist ever to be elected an officer of the big auto maker.

Lee A. Iacocca, former president of the Ford Motor Company and now president and chief operating officer of the Chrysler Corporation, has agreed to submit to a detailed interrogation by Federal prosecutors investigating allegations that Ford Motor paid a bribe to an Indonesian Government official, sources familiar with the case said yesterday.

A CZECHOSLOVAK scientist has come up with a new explanation for what was by far the largest explosion ever recorded on earth. The blast, high in the air over a remote region of Siberia on June 30, 1908, blew down trees for 20 to 30 miles in all directions. Horses 400 miles away were blown off their feet, and residents of a trading station 40 miles away were knocked unconscious and suffered flash burns.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Jan. 29 (AP)--Reginald John Cardinal Delargey, the Roman Catholic Metropolitan of New Zealand, died of cancer today in Auckland, the Government announced.

The Getty Oil Company, the Continental Oil Company and the Sun Company yesterday joined the parade of oil companies reporting higher earnings for 1978's fourth quarter and for the full year.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29--A ghost story and a thriller--"The Changeling," a $6.6 million film starring George C. Scott, and "Agency," a $4 million production starring Robert Mitchum--are pioneering a dramatic change in the Canadian movie industry. NEW DELHI, Jan. 29--The Dalai Lama is ready to talk to the Chinese "if they so desire," a spokesman for the Tibetan spiritual leader said here today.

HONG KONG, Jan. 29--Chinese authorities have reportedly decided to restore "citizen's rights" to millions of former landlords, wealthy villagers and others who had been called "counterrevolutionaries and bad elements" and had been treated as a subclass in rural communes since their holdings were seized and their rights restricted in the early 1950's.

THERE was one "classic" on last night's program of the American Composers Orchestra in Tully Hall. It was "Men and Mountains" by Carl Ruggles, the maverick American composer who died at the age of 95 eight years ago.

WASHINGTON--Few foreign policy initiatives have represented as sharp departures from the past, contained as many innovative ideas or demanded as much diplomatic skill and patience as the Carter Administration's policy toward Africa.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29--Yale University announced today that tuition and room and board fees for the next academic year will total $8,140, an increase of 8.5 percent over the 1978-79 school year.

GENEVA, Jan. 29--Hopes were voiced today for bringing the United States, the world's largest consumer of cocoa, into a pact to stabilize its price. A meeting of 40 nations was opened here by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in an effort to establish such a pact.

SCALI, McCABE, SLOVES, the favorite ad agency of Frank Perdue, now has a chance of also becoming O.J. Simpson's favorite agency: That's because the Ogilvy Mather subsidiary has just been named by the Hertz Corporation to handle advertising for its domestic car renting. WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Environmental Protection Agency conducts extensive aerial photographic surveillance of industrial facilities, usually with out informing the companies involved, as part of its enforcement program, according to documents obtained in a Freedom of Information action.

The American Express Company yesterday raised its offer for McGrawHill Inc. to $40 a share, contingent on an end to what it described as the publishing company's "scorched earth" policy aimed at preventing a takeover.

NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 29--Almost four years after buying one of the great estates on Long Island Sound for use as corporate headquarters, the Continental Group announced today that it was abandoning the plan because of continuing, albelt unsuccessful, litigation by a group of residents.
