A NOVEL theory on the origin of erect posture in human evolution is expected to stimulate discussion and controversy in the wake of the an nouncement 12 days ago of a newly recognized species of human ancestor.

While a number of other major airlines were experiencing losses or sharply curtailed profits, American Airlines Inc. continued its turnaround, apparently right through the end of the year. The company reported preliminary profits yesterday of $8 million for the fourth quarter of 1978, compared with a loss of $12.1 million in the yearearlier period.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29--A 16-year-old girl who calmly told a newspaper reporter by telephone that she was "doing it for fun" opened fire with a rifle at an elementary school today, killing two men and wounding a police officer and eight children.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29--A Dallas Cowboy duo, Roger Staubach and Tony Hill, gave the National Football Conference All-Stars a 13-7 victory over the American Conference team tonight in the Pro Bowl. The game at the Coliseum drew 38,333 fans.

A recent Tax Court decision that went against the Internal Revenue Service seems almost certain to stimulate more interest in Clifford Trusts among the owners of professional corporations and other closely held businesses.
The Golden State Warriors have something to be thankful for--the Knicks.

Terence McCarthy, an economics consultant, died of cancer yesterday at the Margaretville (N.Y.) Memorial Hospital. He was 69 years old and since his retire ment a decade ago had lived in Roxbury, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--President Carter and Teng Hsiao-ping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, opened three days of talks here today with sharply divergent public views on Soviet intentions and on the wisdom of concluding a new strategic arms limitation agreement.

OAXACA, Mexico, Jan. 29--Pope John Paul II visited one of Mexico's most backward regions today and pledged to act as the voice of the poor and oppressed. But few of the 15,000 Indians who listened to him in a village near here understood him.

ALBANY, Jan. 29--Staff experts of the Public Service Commission predict demands for electricity in New York State will grow more slowly in the next 15 years than projected by the public utilities, which already have lowered their estimates of power needs.

ATLANTIC CITY--The Federal Securities and Exchange Commission plans to investigate the activities of Resorts International since 1970, the attorney for the company told the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.
Stock prices staged a modest retreat yesterday in slow trading following last week's show of strength.

ELGAR'S song cycle for contralto and orchestra, "Sea Pictures," does not turn up often in this country, where the general musical public's awareness of the British composer starts and stops with the ...

TRENTON, Jan. 29--Governor Byrne unveiled a 1980 state budget of $4.6 billion today, up $243 million from the present level. Suggesting that the size of the state government may have to be shrunk in the coming years, the Governor sought no new taxes or new programs.

The United Technologies Corporation, which owns 47 percent of the Carrier Corporation stock and hopes to acquire the leading air-conditioning equipment producer this year, reported yesterday a 25 percent jump in fourth-quarter profits on a sales gain of 19 percent.
Steel production for the week ended Jan. 27 rose 5.8 percent to 2.558 million tons from the previous week's 2.418 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A RECENT New York Court of Appeals ruling that held physicians liable in certain circumstances for the lifetime care of children born with some disorders has been applauded by geneticists and consumer groups, but has sent shivers through the medical profession, particularly among obstetricians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--After a longsimmering threat, a strike at the nation's largest shipyard became all but certain today when Federal mediators failed in a final effort to avert the walkout tomorrow of thousands of members of the United Steelworkers of America at the Newport News Shipyard and Dry Dock Company in Virginia's Tidewater area.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 29 (AP)--Jose (Pipino) Cuevas, the 21-year-old slugger from Mexico City, made short work of his eighth World Boxing Association welterweight title defense when he knocked out Scott Clark of Orlando, Fla., in the second round tonight.

Rain in Brazil helped depress soybean prices yesterday for most of the trading session on the Chicago Board of Trade. A rally in the last 15 minutes, however, raised prices to close to Friday's levels in nearby contracts. But while more distant contracts managed to show a slight gain, soybean prices finished mostly lower.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 29 (AP)--Steve Cauthen, the 18-year-old jockey currently mired in a deep losing slump, has been replaced as the rider of Affirmed, Laz Barrera, the horse's trainer, announced today. Barrera named Laffit Pincay to ride the 1978 Triple Crown winner in Sunday's $200,000-added Strub Stakes at Santa Anita.

Ten days from now, Ogden M. (Dinny) Phipps of the New York Racing Association will receive a national Eclipse Award in San Francisco for "distinguished contributions" to the sport of thoroughbred racing in 1978.

LENNIE TRISTANO, the jazz pianist and teacher who died last Nov. 18, left only a handful of recordings, but his influence lives on in the playing of his many students. On Sunday at Town Hall, some musicians who learned from Mr. Tristano participated in a memorial concert that went on for almost six hours and was an impressive tribute to the strength and originality of the pianist's conception.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Carter Administration took its proposal for real wage insurance to the House Ways and Means Committee today amid preliminary signs that the committee's Democrats would approve the measure and send it to the House floor.

WHEN Sir Cyril Burt died in 1971 at the age of 88, The Times of London eulogized him as "the leading figure in Britain in the application of psychology to education and the development of children and the assessment of mental qualities." A prominent American researcher in the same field mourned this "born nobleman" with his "intellect and vast erudition."

LONDON, Tuesday, Jan. 30--Amid indications that some of the strikes that have so disrupted the country this month were ending, Prime Minister James Callaghan met yesterday with Britain's top labor union leaders in an effort to restore his Government's "special relationship" with the unions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Carter Administration said today that since its latest approach for resolving the issues holding up an Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty had failed, a new plan, possibly another Camp David-style summit meeting, would have to be devised.

His 16-year-old son's continued support of The New York Times Neediest Case Fund prompted George J. Nagorski of Manhattan's East Side to double the contribution he made to this year's 67th annual appeal.
TRENTON, Jan. 29--The following are excerpts from Governor Byrne's 1980 state-budget message, which he is to deliver to the New Jersey Legislature tomorrow:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)--Following are the texts of remarks today by President Carter and Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping at a welcoming ceremony for the Chinese leader at the White House.

WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., Jan. 29--Bill Koch, the 23-year-old crosscountry skiing star from Guilford, Vt., stopped for 10 seconds during his 15-kilometer journey today to correct a problem. Then he went on to defeat a teammate, Stan Dunklee, for a national title.

The National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, to $38 million, or $1.98 a share, compared with $16.5 million, or 85 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

THE shares of Beker Industries, a troubled fertilizer company, zoomed last Friday in heavy trading and continued to soar yesterday. The stock advanced 1 3/8 on Friday, a gain of more than 40 percent, and reached 5 early yesterday before closing at 5 1/8, up .

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Carter Administration is struggling to devise a formula to bring banks, some of which are reporting their biggest earnings gains in years, within its wage and price guidelines.
"A widow's mite," said the note attached to one of the thousands of donations received recently by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Khauv Kheong recalls arranging his eldest daughter's marriage in Cambodia, after investigating the prospective bridegroom's family, which had sent "an emissary" to propose the union. He consulted an astrologer, and explained the situation to his daughter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--President Carter commuted the prison sentence of Patricia Hearst today, opening the way for her to leave prison on Thursday.

THERE is no telling why Sayuri Iida chose to open her recital on Jan. 22 at Carnegie Recital Hall with Mozart's Sonata No.7 in C (K. 309). The young Japanese born pianist, a student of Sascha Gorodnitski's at the Juilliard School, dispatched the notes efficiently enough, but, with its brittle articulation and unstinting fortes, her playing conveyed little affection for the piece.
Shinohata people seem frequently to reminisce about the past, generally variations on the theme: how poor we were then, how much better off now.

Megan Marshack, the aide who summoned help after Nelson A. Rockefeller suffered a fatal heart attack last Friday night, did not identify herself or Mr. Rockefeller in a call to the police and was so distraught that police and emergency medical operators had to ask her repeatedly to calm down and clarify the location and nature of the emergency.

Alexis Arguello, the World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, was supposed to be in Rimini, Italy, over the weekend getting ready for next Sunday's televised defense against Alfredo Escalera.
SAN DIEGO, Jan. 29 (AP)--Brenda Spencer's classmates described her today as a tomboy and a gun enthusiast who had difficulty adjusting to school.

Two candidates for the Giants' director-of-operations job were eliminated yesterday--John Ralston, by signing as vice president in charge of administration for the San Francisco 49ers, and Gil Brandt, by apparently being tied up by the Dallas Cowboys through the college draft in May.

KIERKEGAARD once said that he would have been happier as a police spy; he had, he thought, a decided talent for it. This nice relationship between metaphysics and betrayal seems to me to be almost a condition of literary modernism, the weather of our bad dreams. We are all spies, but is there anything to spy on except one another?

By almost all accounts, David Rockefeller is the world's best-known banker. Even before he became chairman and chief executive officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank in 1969 he began converting Chase from a domestic to a global institution.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 29--Prime Minister Shahpur Bakhtiar has announced that a $6.2 billion contract for the construction of two nuclear plants by Framatome, a French concern, has been canceled. Iran had already made a down payment of $240 million on the plants, which were to be built at Darkhoein in the oil-rich southwestern province of Khuzestan.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Following are excerpts from the toasts given by President Carter and senior Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping at the state dinner in Mr. Teng's honor at the White House:

LOS ANGELES--Things look bleak for Gov. Edmund G. "Jerry" Brown on the Presidential front. Although he clobbered Evelle J. Younger in the gubernatorial race in November, the prophets say that it will all be downhill from there. They have a lot of reasons, but they have completely ignored the ...
The rally in the credit markets, which began Jan. 18, continued early yesterday and then faltered during the afternoon, producing the first decline in eight trading days.

GREENVILLE, Miss., Jan. 29--Lieut. Gen. John W. Morris, Chief of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, maintained in Federal Court today that the disputed authority to expand the design of the giant Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway had been granted by the Secretary of the Army and properly financed by Congress in subsequent yearly appropriations.

TUPELO, Miss.--There are no outward signs on the clean-swept downtown streets that this northeastern Mississippi town was the scene last year of several confrontations between militant blacks and the Ku Klux Klan.

A GROUP of research laboratories has developed a technique that, a spokesman says, can tell on the basis of a micro scopic fragment whether the Shroud of Turin is 2,000 years old, as it would have to be if it once covered the body of Jesus.

PARIS, Jan. 29--You wouldn't believe what Paris has in store for you for spring. Well, some of you might-- those who haven't changed their style for 30 years. The Paris couture collections are under way. These are the made-to-order clothes that women from Duluth, Minn., to Cairo yearned for until the rise of ready-to-wear here in the 1960's. Now, of course, they can find clothes with a Paris label at their neighborhood haberdasher.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29--Patricia Hearst yesterday expressed gratitude, pleasure and surprise over President Carter's decision to commute her prison sentence.
James Spicer, for 30 years an organizer in Off Broadway productions and avantgarde jazz, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 240 East 27th Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 29--With a Federal deadline looming, the State Assembly today passed a bill that would lower the insurance rates paid by people in poor neighborhoods who are forced to buy coverage from the state's special highrisk insurance pool.
Digger Phelps, Notre Dame's coach, has the easiest recruiting job in college basketball.
Gerard R. Moran, a professor at the Rutgers University School of Law in Newark, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan.29--The heads of Coca-Cola and Pepsico, the United Auto Workers and General Motors mingled tonight as they all honored Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping at a state dinner at the White House.

Kraft Inc., the world's largest processor of dairy and packaged food products, reported yesterday profit increases of 26 percent for the fourth quarter and 19 percent for all of last year, reflecting improved operating profit here, overseas and Canada.
SINCE his first appearance in this country four years ago Vladimir Spivakov has picked up a sizable following, and one n understand why.

The E.F. Hutton Group reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for 1978. The brokerage firm holding company said that earnings for the year rose 75 percent to $28.2 million, while revenues jumped 56 percent to $522 million.

ABC NEWS documentaries these days are exhibiting pronounced schizoid symptoms. Those tackling sensitive issues from fresh angles, both technical and interpretive, have been encouraging. Two outstanding examples were "Youth Terror" and a portrait of the Palestinians. But those dabbling in inherently sensational subjects, such as the occult, have generated understandable nervousness.

China's leader has come to the United States with a message that, while by no means unexpected or out of character, is still breathtaking. The Soviet Union, says Teng Hsiao-ping, is an international bully that will grab all it can take and may stumble into a world war even though it is already outmaneuvering its adversaries by intrigue and diplomacy.

ILONA HODSON'S high school record in Anchorage, Alaska, was so strong that she was accepted by several of the West Coast's most selective universities, including Stanford. But she decided to attend Washington State University here because the tuition was lower.

POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., Jan. 29-- The ashes of Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller were buried today in a wooded hillside grave site here after a simple service attended only by members of the Rockefeller family.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Chinese political wives don't have it easy, either. The grandmother with the quick, winning smile who stood next to Rosalynn Carter on the South Lawn of the White House today, clutching a handbag that looked like alligator, has twice gone into political oblivion along with her husband.

"Dandelion," a musical fantasy based on Darwin's theory of evolution, featuring the Paper Bag Players, will be performed at the American Museum of Natural History from Feb. 24 through March 18. The show, for adults and children, has been presented at several theaters in England.

DANIEL MALONEY and Dance Company offered six New York premieres Sunday afternoon at Larry Richard son's Dance Gallery. The works were highly uneven in quality, Mr. Maloney proving to be most interesting choreographically when he was exploring some specific theme or idea.

THE sheer dependability of Robert L. Edwards's playing on Jan. 14 at Carnegie Recital Hall made his New York debut recital a pleasure to listen to. The pianist, who teaches at Kansas State University ...

TOKYO, Jan. 29 (AP)--Hitachi Ltd said today that China had contracted to buy 80,000 color television sets, more than eight times the number of sets exported to China last year. Under the contract with China's Ministry of Light Industries, Hitachi will ship 10,000 of its 20-inch sets every month starting in March, a spokesman for the giant electrical concern said. He did not disclose the value of the contract

FOR his Collegiate Chorale program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, Richard Westenburg selected two religious works that lent themselves to gentle, introspective treatment and treated them both just that way.

The New York City Schools Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola, yesterday praised Governor Carey's new budget formula, which is designed to equalize the financing of public schools, but warned that it was crucial that the Legislature insure that the funds be spend to improve education rather than to cut local property taxes.

Major New York banks lowered the interest rate they charge on loans to securities dealers by one-half percentage point to 11 percent, but loan officers said they thought the reduction would not lead to a general reduction in rates of corporate loans. The prime rate, now 11 percent, should remain there, they said.

Dolphin D. Overton 3d mortgaged everything he owns to finance the projected purchase, anounced last Friday, of the Liggett Myers Tobacco Company, the domestic cigarette operations of the Liggett Group, for about $122 million. Was it a good idea?

Moving north against the southerly flowing rush-hour traffic on Manhattan's Second Avenue, the express bus headed toward the Queensboro Bridge at 59th Street like a rebellious buffalo defying the will of the herd.

BOSTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--A group of scientists charged today that the Federal Government was more interested in pro tecting itself than in listening to researchers who found a possible link between cancer and nuclear shipyard radiation exposure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The Department of Energy indicated today that the price of gasoline at the pump would go up 14 to 18 cents a gallon over the next two years, considerably more than previously estimated.
The venerable mill city of Paterson, N.J., is moving forward with a downtown revival effort based on the notion of re-use of the underutilized mills themselves.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP)--Two major labor unions asked the Department of Health, Education and Welfare today to take over occupational radiation health studies that have been conducted by the Energy Department.

ROME, Jan. 30 (AP)--Giuseppe Spataro, who helped found the Christian Democratic Party at the end of World War II and who was a member of several cabinets in the postwar years, died today of pneumonia at his home in Rome. He was 81 years old.

A Long Island Rail Road train jumped the tracks at the Port Washington station last night, suspending overnight service between Port Washington and Great Neck and leaving this morning's service in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--After recent meetings with President Carter's Council of Economic Advisers, the new Office of Surface Mining today proposed ways of protecting strip-mined land that the office said would cost coal companies "a little less" than the regulations proposed last September.

THE West German Finance Minister, Hans Matthofer, was in the United States this week to confer with his counterpart, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal, to try to get a clearer picture of where the United States economy and the dollar are heading.

WASHINGTON,. Jan 30--The trade deficit of the United States in December was $2.04 billion, lifting the excess of imports over exports for all 1978 to $28.45 billion, a record, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Bella Abzug and the woman who replaced her as head of the National Women's Advisory Committee disagreed tonight on whether the panel had lost its credibility since Mrs. Abzug's dismissal.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia--Southern Africa's whites are facing not only a crisis of race relations but something that may be still more portentous: the end of the automobile way of life.
The credit markets, after muddling through most of the day, resumed their rally late yesterday after the Chase Manhattan Bank lowered its prime rate to 11 percent from 11 percent.
Corporate takeover situations produced the biggest market winners yesterday, as stocks generally moved lower after a brief afternoon rally.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 30--In his first major speech to the Cambodian people, the President of the Vietnamese-installed Government has delivered a bitter indictment of the regime of the routed Prime Minister, Pol Pot, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Ieng Sary.
The Washington Steel Corporation said its directors had rejected the latest tender offer from Talley Industries as not being in the best interest of its shareholders or the company.

The American people generally support President Carter's tight budget, seeing spending cuts as a key way to curb inflation, but they still want to make exceptions for particular programs or tax breaks, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--The program to cut taxes presented today by Governor Carey is aimed primarily at certain groups--small and medium-sized corporations, three specific industries, the elderly and those earning more than $19,000 a year. Several of the measures, the Governor said, were aimed at keeping "business decision-makers" from moving out of the state.
New construction in the United States showed only moderate gains in December and all 1978 after adjustment for inflation, according to a McGraw-Hill survey issued yesterday.

VANESSA" comes to televi sion this evening, at 8:30 on Channel 13, and the 1958 Pu litzer Prize opera takes hauntingly well to the small screen.

THE dulcet combination of flute and guitar is an unusually compatible one and very hard to resist.
A special commission of the Rabbinical Assembly, which represents the Conservative branch of Judaism, has recommended that "qualified women be ordained as rabbis."
LONDON, Jan. 30--The strike by truck drivers that has crippled British industry for more than three weeks appeared to be nearing an end today on terms close to what the strikers had sought.

Darius Kapadia, a 28-year-old native of Nagpur, India, recalled yesterday an old Lebanese expression, "If you succeed in Beirut, you'll succeed anywhere in the world." And Mr. Kapadia, who did succeed in Beirut, at least for a while, is now proving the point.

TORONTO, Jan. 30 (Reuters)--The Canadian subsidiary of Levi Strauss Company of San Francisco was fined $150,000 (Canadian) here for price fixing and refusing to supply retailers who sold its products at discount prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--The United States today ordered the evacuation of all dependents and nonessential American officials in Iran and urged that other American citizens leave as well because of worsening security there.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30--Pete Rose brought his traveling act to this university town today in a new and even novel role: ticket-seller for the Philadelphia Phillies. But his new employers said they had no qualms about the $800,000 they must pay him this season because it was already in the till.

SUDDENLY productivity, or output per manhour, has become the watchword, newly stressed by President Carter's closest economic counselors as the real ceiling on the nation's economic growth. And along with that has come a worry over the decline in technological innovation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 30--Over strong objections by an assistant attorney general, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted 5 to 0 today not to prosecute a former executive of Resorts International for contempt stemming from his refusal to reveal publicly the name of a Bahamian official with whom he had dealt.

TOKYO, Jan. 30--The Soviet Union has stationed about 5,000 troops on two islands off the coast of Hokkaido, the northernmost of the main Japanese islands, and is building bases there, Japanese officials said today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 30--The Iranian Government tonight authorized the return of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and the elderly Moslem leader began preparing for a flight home Thursday from exile in France.
A minor earthquake shook floors and rattled windows throughout central New Jersey yesterday and its tremors reached across Staten Island and into southern Brooklyn.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Carey proposed a $12.7 billion budget today for the 1979-80 fiscal year that included modest tax cuts over three years, limited increases in local aid and an admonition to local governments to contain spending.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Representative Henry A. Waxman, a liberal California Democrat who gave $24,000 in campaign funds last fall to 10 members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, won the chairmanship of that panel's influential Health and Environment Subcommittee today.

PALISADES, N.Y., Jan. 30--Richard Quittmeyer was the first to notice that the little red lines on the Helicorder seismographs had begun to jitterbug off their normal paths at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--The new formula proposed by Governor Carey for state revenue-sharing would give local governments almost $90 million less than what they would receive if the existing formula were continued. And over the years, it would dramatically slow the growth rate of aid to localities.
The New York Philharmonic has received a $750,000 grant from the Charles E. Culpeper Foundation to endow the concertmaster's chair.

ATLANTA, Jan. 30--Spokesmen for a coalition of conservative activists, ministers and anti-Communist Chinese living here announced plans today for demonstrations against the visit of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping on Thursday.

George Dunham Jr., a retired television executive, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 69 years old.

Lawrence P. Fraiberg, president of Metromedia Television, the national broadcast group that operates WNEWTV, Channel 5, in New York, has resigned with the explanation that he wished to return to his former career as an independent producer of programs. He said in a statement he would continue as executive producer of Metromedia's cultural and children's programming.

President Carter said the report by the Carnegie Commission on the Future of Public Broadcasting would provide a "focal point" for continued discussions by Government and public broadcasting on the industry's future.
The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its profits for the fourth quarter soared to $94.6 million from a quarterly low of $9 million in the final quarter of 1977.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--China has rejected, at least temporarily, the applications of two American social scientists who were scheduled to begin research there this spring. The move raises an important question of reciprocity in Chinese-American relations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that it would be "premature" to say that interest rates have peaked. He suggested they would have to go higher if the robust economic growth of late last year continued.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30--Long lines of people have become a familiar sight outside the Los Angeles Superior Court building where Lee Marvin, the actor, is defending himself against a suit in which the woman he lived with for more than six years is seeking more than $1 million.
About three dozen burglar-alarm company trucks circled City Hall Plaza yesterday to protest a decision by the Police Department to downgrade the priority of its response to automatic burglar alarms.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--A new proposal to combat inflation, a constitutional amendment that would tie increases in Government spending to the nation's economic growth, was unveiled today by a committee of relatively conservative businessmen and economists as an alternative to requiring a balanced Federal budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Like many freshman Congressmen, Michael L. Synar ran on a platform of balanced budgets and efficient government. But last week, when President Carter's budget was submittted to Congress, Mr. Synar was horrified at the proposal to slice $400 million out of a sewage construction program.

Nelson A. Rockefeller was treated shortly before his death by his physician for symptoms of a heart ailment, Dr. Michael M. Baden, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, said yesterday.

After two years in office, President Carter still inspires a firm image of honesty and competence among the American people, but a majority of the public think he has not turned out to be a strong leader, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News national poll.
HONG KONG, Jan. 31 (Reuters)-- North Korea announced today that it will stop its propaganda war against the South as a first step toward ending hostility between the two states.

PARIS, Jan. 29 (Reuters)--Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel began an official two-day visit to France today by meeting with Prime Minister Raymond Barre. Officials said he would also hold talks with Jean Francois-Poncet, the Foreign Minister, primarily on the IsraeliEgyptian peace negotiations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (UPI)--The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that there were 342 banks on the agency's "problem list" at the end of 1978.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 30 (AP)--Circus Maximus, owned and captained by John Raby of Rahway, N.J., took the early lead today in a 370mile sailing race from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale. Raby's boat was pulling away fast when the fleet was last sighted some 25 miles away.

SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 30 (AP)-- South Korea had a trade surplus of $1.03 billion with the United States in 1978, up 53 percent from $670 million in the previous year, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today.

Malcolm Muir, who began as a file clerk and rose to head the boards of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company and, later, Newsweek magazine, died of bronchial pneumonia yesterday at his home at 435 East 52d Street. He was 93 years old.

A wild song sparrow has taken up residence in a Greenwich Village flower shop. The small brown bird flew into Flowers by Arno, at 18 West Eighth Street, last October and has remained there even though the shop's door was wide open for a month after its arrival.

RICHMOND, Jan. 30 (AP)-- Bjorn Borg, Jimmy Connors's chief rival for No. 1 in the world, returned to the court tonight for the first time in a month and defeated Erik van Dillen, 6-4, 6-4, in the opening round of a $175,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

Shirley Adelson Siegel was promoted yesterday to Solicitor General of New York by Attorney General Robert Abrams. An employee in the Attorney General's office since 1974, she had been assistant solicitor general. Mrs. Siegel, based in Albany, will supervise the department's statewide litigation and appellate work.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 (AP)-- The Philadelphia Flyers, in their worst slump in eight years, dismissed Coach Bob McCammon and his assistant, Terry Crisp, today. McCammon was replaced by Pat Quinn, coach of the Flyers' Maine farm team in the American Hockey League.

Citicorp, taking advantage of the late January rally in the credit markets, speeded up its floating-rate note sale, increased its size to $500 million from $200 million and priced the issue initially to yield 11.05 percent.

The basic money supply declined by $3.1 billion in the week ended Jan. 24, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This was a sharper drop than most money market analysts had expected. Most had predicted a shift somewhere between a decline of $2 billion and a rise of $1 billion.
New Jersey now subsidizes 22 private bus companies but they are all losing money. Bus service is redundant on some routes, spotty on others and totally lacking elsewhere.

By all accounts, there has been euphoria at the Ford Foundation ever since it was announced on Monday that Franklin A. Thomas had been chosen to become president when McGeorge Bundy retires in June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut called on the state's Congressional delegation today to help restore President Carter's budget cutbacks, but she was told that the "new reality" in Washington meant the state would have to live with at least some of the cuts.

The Brunswick Corporation of Skokie, Ill., manufacturer of leisuretime and other products, reported yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter climbed 8.7 percent to a record while sales advanced 17.9 percent, also to a record. TOKYO, Feb. 2 (UPI) Despite the dollar's slide in value, Japan's 1978 balance-of-payments surplus surged 50 percent to a record $16.63 billion on its current account, official figures showed today. The 1977 surplus was $10.92 billion in the account, which covers goods, services and all financial transactions.

It is more than two years since Orlando Letelier, Chile's Foreign Minister and Ambassador to Washington during the Allende era, was murdered along with Ronni Moffitt, his American aide, by a car bomb in Washington. United States prosecutors believe the bombing was ordered by high officials of Chile's secret police agency, then known as the DINA. But these officials remain beyond the reach of justice.

HOUSTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) An unarmed man lunged in the direction of Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping in a hotel basement today but was quickly subdued by Secret Service officers. Mr. Teng, on his way to a waiting car, was about 15 feet away at the time and was not touched.

MOSCOW, Feb. 2 Every schoolchild knows that an election in the Soviet Union offers a choice of only one candidate the Communist Party candidate. But today a small group of workers, Russian nationalists, religious activists and others announced an attempt to change that, an effort that may constitute one of Moscow's strangest political events in years.

The board of directors of the Pennsylvania Life Company approved yesterday a previously proposed definitive merger agreement with Ticor, a title insurance concern. Ticor's board previously approved the transaction.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has decided that "no further investigation or prosecution is warranted" into charges that President Carter or a White House aide illegally solicited political contributions of a White House luncheon last August, it was disclosed today.

IN an unpublicized meeting at Williamsburg, Va., last week, 40 academic and corporate executives spent two days discussing the problems they share and the barriers between them. The session, organized by J.W. Pel tason, president of the American Council on Education, was a trial balloon for the creation of a powerful "business-higher education forum."

ALTHOUGH it kills guinea pigs and thus might never have been approved for use on humans if it were developed under modern regulations, penicillin, which revolutionized the practice of medicine when it was introduced in World War II, remains a "wonder drug" almost 40 years later, and its importance is still growing.

SEATTLE, Feb. 5 Ailing from what was described officially as a slight fever but seemingly elated by his reception in the United States, Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping of China ended his nineday visit today by holding out a prospect of ever-expanding cooperation.
John Russell, an art critic for The New York Times, has received the Frank Jewett Mather Award for Art Criticism, given annually by the College Art Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Securities and Exchange Commission officially closed its three-year investigation into New York City's financial crisis today without taking any enforcement action against the city officials and institutions that were criticized in a 1977 commission report.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 5 Bergen County Superior Court Judge Morris Malech placed Lew Williams, a harness driver, on six months' probation today as a result of a five-court indictment against him on a charge of possessing drugs.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 Boston University defeated Harvard, 4-2, and Boston College routed Northeastern, 7-2, before 14,769 spectators at Boston Garden tonight in the first round of the 27th annual Beanpot hockey tournament. The winners will meet next Monday for the championship.
LONDON, Feb. 5 (Reuters) A British magistrate ordered today that Astrid Proll, a suspected terrorist, be extradited to West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) President Carter today designated the week of March 4 as Save Your Vision Week. He urged Americans to consider "what they can do to take care of their eyes and protect them from disease and injury."

The Reliance Group will not acquire the W. R. Berkley Corporation after all. Reliance agreed in principle on Jan. 23 to pay $23 a share for Berkley, a property and casualty insurance company. The agreement has been terminated, Reliance said yesterday.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Feb. 5 (AP) The California Angels announced today that since signing Rod Carew they had sold 250 season tickets, including a pair to former President Richard M. Nixon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The General Accounting Office declared today that it would be illegal for the Government to make a company ineligible for a Federal contract on the ground that the company had failed to comply with the Administration's antiinflation price-wage standards.

TULSA, Okla., Feb. 5 (AP) City bus drivers staged a wildcat strike today, protesting an alleged failure by the Metropolitan Tulsa Transit Authority to provide a relief driver quickly after a driver suffered a stroke last week. Eugene Gooding, general manager of the authority, said that as far as he knew a relief driver was sent immediately. The drivers gave no indication how long they would remain off the routes.

FRANKFURT, Feb. 5 (AP) The overall West German 1978 balance of payments produced a surplus of $10.5 billion, up from a surplus of $5.5 billion in 1977, according to preliminary figures released today by the Deutsche Bundesbank. The figures showed declines in the December surplus, however. The current-account surplus, including the trade, transfer and services accounts, was $8.6 billion in 1978, almost double the 1977 surplus of $4.6 billion, according to Bundesbank figures.

ALDERSON, W.Va., Feb. 5 (AP) Sara Jane Moore, who was convicted of trying to assassinate President Ford in 1975, escaped from a minimum-security Federal prison here tonight but was recaptured about four hours later, the police said.

Perry fell down some stairs and cut his right hand on a television set at the bottom of the stairs. Doctors who treated him at Pitt Memorial Hospital said there was no muscle, tendon or nerve damage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Iranian upheaval has confronted the Carter Administration with some difficult questions concerning the future of American arms sales, and officials and members of Congress have begun to debate the lessons of the United States' involvement in Iran.
Despite the inflationary climate confronting food processors, higher sales and earnings were reported yesterday by three companies.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 5 (UPI) Because of a Federal court ruling, the huge Tennessee Valley Authority may have to relocate its headquarters to Muscle Shoals, Ala., a move that could have an enormous economic impact not only for the two states but also for the American taxpayer.
Stock prices broke sharply yesterday as political turmoil in Iran and implications of the reduced flow of oil from the Middle East cast a long shadow across Wall Street.

TEL AVIV, Feb. 5 Shots were fired and stones thrown today in a clash between Arab high school students and Jewish settlers on the West Bank. Armed Israelis later stormed the Arab high school and detained the principal, Jalal Aref.

TEHERAN, Iran Feb. 5 This city, which overflowed with excitement and joy on the warm bright morning last week when Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini came home from exile, was calm, grimly approving, but apprehensive tonight when it learned that Iran had two prime ministers.

Steel production for the week ended last Saturday rose to 2.63 million tons, up 2.7 percent from the previous week's total of 2.56 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink announced today that he had dropped 215 of the 750 people from the portion of the Assembly payroll under his direct control, a move he said would save $1.2 million a year.

One of the decisions made by the National Basketball Association owners at the recent All-Star game was to expand by two teams no later than the 1980-81 season. Although seven cities have been mentioned, the ones most likely to get franchises are Minneapolis-St. Paul and Dallas-Fort Worth.

"Pupofon," a production from Vienna that combines puppetry with live actors, will begin a limited run tomorrow at La Mama Experimental Theater, 74A East Fourth Street.

Reacting largely to the weakness in the dollar in foreign-exchange trading, the credit markets dropped sharply yesterday in a move that wiped out much of the gains of last week. It was the first pronounced increase in interest rates so far this year.

The New York Philharmonic raised $305,740 in its second annual "phone festival," which ended on Sunday night. The event was carried by radio station WQXR for 56 hours, beginning Thursday night, and was broadcast from the chorus room of Avery Fisher Hall, with the phones manned by volunteers. The first festival last year raised $277,000.
LONDON, Feb. 5 Stock markets and the dollar were hit by heavy selling today, and precious metals prices soared as turbulence in Iran upset financial dealings around the world.

In response to President Carter's pay stabilization program, 73 percent of the companies participating in a national survey have cut back their employee pay plans for 1979, according to a report yesterday by the Princeton, N.J., management consulting firm of Sibson Company.

Reversing a ruling in State Supreme Court, the Appellate Division yesterday ordered Robert Torsney -- the white police officer acquitted by reason of insanity in the killing of a black youth -- be kept in a state mental hospital.

BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI) The Lockheed Corporation said today that British Airways had ordered two more L-1011 Tristar aircraft valued at almost $100 million including spare parts. The Tristars will be powered by Rolls-Royce RB211-524B engines. This brings to 23 the carrier's firm orders and options for Tristars.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 5 (AP) Mildred Gordon, who with her husband wrote 20 novels that sold an estimated 16 million copies, died of bone cancer on Saturday. She was 73 years old.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Tuesday, Feb. 6 -- The Supreme Court of Pakistan today upheld the sentence of death passed upon former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto and four others for conspiracy to murder a political opponent nearly five years ago.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Feb. 5 Drawn by a carrot, pushed by a stick, two giant American auto makers, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, are quietly creating more jobs for unskilled and semiskilled workers of this Rio Grande border city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the next attempt to break the impasse over a peace treaty between Egypt and Israel would be "a meeting at the ministerial level at which we will try to grapple with the issues as a whole."

John Walker of New Zealand, the Olympic 1,500-meter champion and mile-record holder, lashed out yesterday at what he called apathy shown by the United States and other Western nations in track and field and predicted a medal runaway by the Communist bloc in the 1980 Moscow Olympics.

Sugar Ray Leonard said yesterday that he expected to fight for one of the world welterweight titles by September, then capture one of the world junior middleweight crowns before moving into the middleweight division next year.

CLEVELAND TAKE a piece of cotton sewing thread, heat it until it is charred black, put it in an evacuated glass sphere and pass electricity through it. One hundred years ago, Thomas Alva Edison did just that, and the light cast by his filament signalled the dawn of the Electric Age.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 5 (AP) Tracy Jackson, Notre Dame's outstanding sixth man, scored 18 points tonight to lead top-ranked Notre Dame to an 84-66 triumph over Loyola of Chicago in college basketball.

Simon Gourdine, the deputy commissioner of the N.B.A., has taken a 14week leave of absence to attend an advanced management program at Harvard. WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) This nation's population reached 220 million at 10:45 A.M. today, but nobody will ever know the identity of the 220-millionth American, according to the Census Bureau.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 5 Almost 200 students at public schools here were sent home this morning because they had not produced evidence of inoculation against six childhood diseases. SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP) Three men charged with burglary escaped from the Schenectady County Jail, sheriff's deputies said today. The men were identified as Edward Karl 3d, 22 years old; Douglas Hyson, 23, and Jack Brandow Jr., 21.
